data.title: BFI Southbank Programme December 2018
data.text:
December 2018 programme for the BFI Southbank. The front cover is an image from Tim Burton's A Nightmare Before Christmas. The contents page of the programme is separated into In Person & Previews, New Releases, Re-Releases, Member Exclusives, their regular programme and Seasons: Comedy Genius, Jane Fonda, Animation 2018, Big Screen Classics and special films and events. The Previews and In Person section includes screenings such as: TV Preview of 'Sound of Music Musicals', Mark Kermode Live in 3D, a 'Mrs Brown's Boys Christmas Special'. New releases includes: 'Disobedience' (Sebastian Lelio, 2017), 'Sorry to Bother You' (Boots Riley, 2018). The re-releases include: 'It's a Wonderful Life' (Capra, 1946). Comedy Genius season includes 'Groundhog Day' with a life performance from Comedians Cinema Club, a slapsteak section which includes a Buster Keaton double-bill, Laural and Hardy's final film 'Utopia' and Charlie Chaplin shorts. There is a section, on English Eccentrics, including films such as: 'Withnail & I' (dir. Bruce Robinson, 1987), 'Kind Hearts and Coronets' (Richard Hamer, 1949), 'The Belles of St. Trinian's' (Frank Launder, 1954), 'Monty Puthon's Life of Brian' (Terry Jones, 1979). Christmas comedia section includes: 'Trading Places' (John Landis, 1983), 'The Apartment' (Billy Wilder, 1960), 'Bad Santa' (Terry Zwigoff, 2003) and Home Alone (Chris Columbus, 1990). For projecting the archive the film is: 'Traveller's Joy' (Ralph Thomas, 1950). The Jane Fonda season continues from November programme and includes films such as: 'Julia' (Fred Zinnermann, 1977), 'On Golden Pond' (Mark Rydell, 1981), and 'Youth' (Paolo Sorrentino, 2015). Animation 2018 includes such films as 'The Nightmare Before Christmas' (Tim Burton, 1993). The Big Screen classics include films such as 'Bicycle Theives' (Vittorio De Sica, 1948), Tokyo Story, (Yasuijiro Ozo, 1953), 'The House of Mirth' (Terence Davies, 2000), 'All the Heaven Allows' (Douglas Sirk, 1955) and 'Barry Lyndon' (Stanley Kubrick, 1975). The special films and events include a talk on Why Rachel Low Matters, a screening of 'The First Born' (Miles Mander, 1928) with an intro from Christine Gledhill. Screening to celebrate 15th anniversity of 'Thirteen' (Cartherine Hardwicke, 2003). Second part is a pull out calendar for the upcoming films and events. Cover includes an image for 'Sorry to Bother You'.

Item number 65316 Category Programme Type Cinema Publicity Language English Country of origin UK
